clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign, rare tumor of odontogenic origin* Encapsulated, characterized by spindled or cuboidal epithelium forming a nodular pattern, with duct-like structures resulting in cribriform areas; eosinophilic amyloid and calcifications may be seen ([Head Neck Pathol 2021;15:71](33723756))

Essential features

* Adenomatoid odontogenic tumors (AOTs) are most common in the anterior region of the jaws in young female patients associated with impacted teeth ([J Nat Sci Biol Med 2013;4:457](24082751))* Microscopically, AOTs contain spindled, cuboidal, polygonal epithelium, forming duct-like structures, whorls and cribriform architecture surrounded by a thick capsule* Eosinophilic matrix may be seen, which can calcify ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2022;133:675](35165067))* Also called the tumor of two - thirds as two - thirds of cases occur in female patients in the maxilla, surrounding an impacted tooth ([Oral Oncol 1999;35:125](10435145), [Surg Pathol Clin 2017;10:177](28153133))

Terminology

* Historic terminology (no longer appropriate) includes adenoameloblastoma, adenoameloblastic odontoma, adenomatoid ameloblastoma, pseudoadenomatous ameloblastoma ([J Oral Pathol Med 1991;20:149](2061853))* In 1971, the World Health Organization (WHO) adopted terminology proposed by Philipsen and Birn: adenomatoid odontogenic tumor ([Acta Pathol Microbiol Scand 1969;75:375](5801660))

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [9300/0](https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=89) - adenomatoid odontogenic tumor* ICD-10
    + [D16.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.4) - benign neoplasm of bones of skull and face+ [D16.5](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.5) - benign neoplasm of lower jaw bone

Epidemiology

* 2.2 - 7.1% of all odontogenic tumors ([J Oral Med Oral Surg 2021;27:19](https://doi.org/10.1051/mbcb/2020053), [J Oral Pathol Med 2007;36:383](17617830))
  + 87.2% occur in the second or third decade of life but may occur across wide age range* ~2:1 female predilection* 3 variants of AOT are follicular (pericoronal), extrafollicular and peripheral ([J Oral Pathol Med 2007;36:383](17617830))
      + Follicular variant accounts for ~71% of all cases+ Extrafollicular (extracoronal) variant accounts for ~27% of cases+ Peripheral (extraosseous) variant accounts for 2% of all cases

Sites

* Anterior maxilla is the most affected (66.6%) ([Head Neck Pathol 2012;6:430](22869356))
  + ~42% of cases are associated with impacted maxillary canines ([J Oral Pathol Med 1991;20:149](2061853))* There is a significant predilection for the anterior region (93.3%), with only 6.7% of cases affecting the posterior area, exclusively in the mandible ([Head Neck Pathol 2012;6:430](22869356))

Pathophysiology

* *KRAS* mutations and MAPK pathway activation are commonly implicated in the pathogenesis in AOT* In one series, 71% (27/38) of AOT cases expressed *KRAS* codon 12 mutations ([Mod Pathol 2019;32:799](30643167))

Clinical features

* Usually an asymptomatic swelling (unless secondarily infected)* Tooth displacement may be present

Diagnosis

* May be detected radiographically as an incidental finding or present as clinical swelling

Radiology description

* Most commonly (~75%) appear as well defined, unilocular radiolucencies ([J Oral Pathol Med 2007;36:383](17617830))
  + May also appear as mixed density or opaque lesions* Encompass impacted teeth and extend beyond the cementoenamel junction and sometimes continue to the apex ([Quintessence Int 2022;53:260](34709771))

Radiology images

Images hosted on other servers:  

[![Radiolucency, engulfing tooth, extending beyond crown](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandibleAOTpubmed001.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4100378/figure/fig1/)

Radiolucency, engulfing tooth, extending beyond crown

Prognostic factors

* Prognosis excellent, few recurrences (< 5% documented)

Case reports

* 17 year old girl with a 2 cm maxillary lesion surrounding an impacted canine tooth ([Case #490](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/caseofweek/case490.htm))* 18 year old woman with nonpainful lesion of right anterior maxilla ([Anticancer Res 2013;33:2673](23749926))* 28 year old man with impacted tooth ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2003;127:e173](12653614))* 31 year old man with cystic radiolucent lesion of the right mandible ([J Oral Med Oral Surg 2021;27:19](https://doi.org/10.1051/mbcb/2020053))

Treatment

* Generally treated by surgical enucleation* Cases of large lesions that have caused significant bone loss and thinning are often managed by insertion of a drain or via marsupialization ([Maxillofac Plast Reconstr Surg 2014;36:173](27489830))* Both surgical and orthodontic modalities can be used to preserve the associated impacted tooth ([Maxillofac Plast Reconstr Surg 2014;36:173](27489830))

Gross description

* 1 - 3 cm in size, unicystic with a thick capsule and soft tissue filling most of the cystic space

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Epithelium may appear nodular, trabecular, cribriform and form duct-like structures
  + Cells may be spindly, cuboidal or columnar with the nuclei palisading away from the lumen+ Lesion is enclosed in a thick capsule* Amyloid deposits may be present ([Quintessence Int 2022;53:260](34709771))* Calcifications may be seen* Calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor (CEOT)-like areas may be seen
        + AOT - CEOT hybrid lesions have been described as distinct entities; these are customarily considered to be an AOT variant, with the clinical behavior of AOT* References: [Head Neck Pathol 2017;11:519](27817004), [Oral Oncol 2005;41:835](15979930)

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Elizabeth Ann Bilodeau, D.M.D., M.D., M.S.Ed. and Kelly Magliocca, D.D.S., M.P.H. ([Case #490](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/caseofweek/case490.htm))  

[![Thick fibrous capsule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau01.jpg)

Thick fibrous capsule

[![Cribriform areas](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau02.jpg)

Cribriform areas

[![Rosette-like structure](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau03.jpg)

Rosette-like structure

[![Cellular area with focal matrix deposition](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandibleAOTbilodeau04.jpg)

Cellular area with focal matrix deposition

[![Nodular appearance](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca11.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillawhoMagliocca11.jpg)

Nodular appearance

[![Thick capsule](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/caseofweek/case490img1.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/caseofweek/case490img1.jpg)

Thick capsule

Positive stains

* [AE1 / AE3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html) ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2022;133:675](35165067))* [CK5](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck5and6.html), [CK17](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck17.html) and [CK19](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck19.html) ([J Oral Pathol Med 2003;32:55](12558960))* [Congo red](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscongored.html) may highlight focal amyloid deposits, especially in CEOT-like areas ([Oral Oncol 2005;41:835](15979930))

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* *KRAS* mutations and MAPK pathway activation are commonly implicated in the pathogenesis of AOT ([Mod Pathol 2019;32:799](30643167))

Sample pathology report

* Anterior maxilla, left, excisional biopsy:
  + Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor, 1.8 cm

Differential diagnosis

* [Adenoid ameloblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastoma.html):
  + May have extensive dentinoid clear cells and occasional ghost cells+ Morules / whorls, duct-like structures may be seen+ Lacks thick capsule, radiographically often not well defined* [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html):
    + Ameloblastic epithelium and ghost cells+ Lacks whorls, duct-like structures and cribriform architecture* [Calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingepithelial.html):
      + Sheets of polygonal cells with pleomorphism and prominent intercellular bridging+ Lacks architectural pleomorphism (whorls, cribriform, duct-like pattern)

Additional references

* [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Head and Neck Tumours, 5th Edition, 2024](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283245148/pathologyoutl-20)
